ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned how to set type and operate a printing press to create a piece of ephemera, a broadside, and a book

This class teaches you the basics of the printing press, knowledge and skills that you don't have the opportunity to learn just anywhere. It makes for an easy going arts & humanities credit: you are very independent, working on various projects (ephemera, broadside, a small book, and a final paper) and determining the artistic process according to your interests. You can really print whatever you want, once you learn the ins-and-outs of using type!
I learned so much about printing and the history of typesetting, and most notably, how to do it myself!
Knowledge in the printing and operations of the letterpress, as well as project planning and time-management

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: hard to get a lot of work done during class time, so needed to come in to the press a lot outside of class to get projects done, but it was always very easy to get access to work when it was convenient for me. Jesse is great and cares a lot about his craft and seeing his students succeed, but that also translates into long-windedness when he is lecturing, and he will just talk at you for hours. Although the lecture content (about history of fonts and influential printers) is interesting, none of it is particularly useful/there is no application for it so it is really hard to stay focused and engaged. the actual project work though is really fun  highly recommended easy art course.
I don't think that it should meet during reading period/finals.
Strenghts-- engaging hands on work with the printing press. great assistance from sid the teaching fellow. leture classes were not the most engaging-- not the most participatory and very long

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: fun easy art course. no prior experience needed, pretty much all materials provided. you should just be prepared to invest a lot of time outside of class to work on the projects, since you have to physically be in the pressroom to get work done.
Yes, I would recommend this course. If you can fit in a good few extra hours into your week to work on very hands-on art projects, then you should definitely take this course.
yes! such a wonderful course and a lovely learning environment, I truly value my time in the press.
Yes-- to a certain kind of student who enjoys hands-on craft and can commit a lot of class time alone to the process, i would totally recommend
Yes, it's a great way to take advantage of what Yale has to offer and to engage in a different kind of learning.

extras.title: ART 106 01 - Art of the Printed Word
